docs.lead_paragraph: IT wasn't so long ago that leukemia was an almost certain death sentence, often within a few months of its discovery. Little could be done for victims, about half of whom were children. Today, the picture is far brighter; indeed, leukemia, especially in children, is one of medical science's success stories. A youngster struck by the most common form of the disease today, acute lymphocytic leukemia, has a 50-50 chance of being alive and well five or more years after diagnosis, which is tantamount to cure in nearly all cases.
